p: The substitution of saturated fatty acids in the diet with other nutrients, according to available evidence, may yield different results: the substitution of polyunsaturated and monounsaturated fats (but not that of total carbohydrates, refined complex carbohydrates, or sugars) for saturated fats was associated, in two large US cohorts, with a reduction of CHD risk [ 42]. It should be considered that such observation could be attributed to the possible beneficial effect of polyunsaturated and monounsaturated fatty acids and not necessarily to an adverse effect of saturated fatty acids (SFAs) [ 36].
